statements.statement: I do not think that it is technically feasible to replace all heating systems in the existing building stock in Bellingham with electric heat pumps.
Building electrification is necessary to achieve carbon neutrality.
There are so many other things to worry about that are much bigger than natural gas.
The benefits of implementing these measures would outweigh the challenges.
Electricity costs too much compared to natural gas.
It is important to me to have a gas range to cook on.
Having gas backup is important for if electricity goes out.
I want to have the potential for energy options in my home or office.
The consumer should be able to choose what type of energy they use for space and water heating.
Let the market decide whether or not transitioning to electric systems and appliances makes sense.
The City should focus on promoting incentives for installing efficient, electric appliances.
I do not care if I use gas or electric appliances in my house, so long as I have a warm house and warm water.
We should focus on promoting energy efficiency in our existing and future building stock.
The transition away from fossil fuels, including natural gas, is inevitable.
We need to source our electricity from 100% renewables before we implement the electrification measures.
We need to prioritize a process for overcoming the cost barrier associated with the transition to primarily electric systems and appliances.
There needs to be a deeper economic analysis to understand the true costs of implementing these measures.
I want to be conscious of how we use our natural resources.
Human-caused climate change is not a completely settled science.
Climate change is a pressing issue.
We need to prioritize reducing our greenhouse gas emissions.
In considering these measures, Bellingham is right in line with where every city needs to curb the worst effects of climate change.
I believe that there are enough people in the City that can afford to electrify their houses and appliances on their own without being forced.
The City should take the lead in implementing climate policy.
The City should prioritize transitioning their own City buildings to use only efficient electric space and water heating systems.
I want a gas furnace in my house.
I will voluntarily install a heat pump or other efficient electric system in my house or office when I replace my existing space and water heating system.
We need to consider the viability of our natural gas providers as we transition to a more sustainable future.
I am concerned that community members will lose their jobs if these measures are adopted.
We will see a community wide benefit of job creation if we adopt these measures.
People won't want to move to Bellingham if these electrification measures are adopted.
We must prioritize making housing more affordable in our community.
The upfront capital cost is the number one barrier to installing efficient, electric heating systems, like heat pumps, for a large percentage of people.
Transitioning the building stock to use primarily electric systems and appliances would increase the cost of housing in Bellingham.
Businesses won't want to do business in Bellingham if these measures are adopted.
There needs to be deeper consideration of public input before these measures are adopted.
There are major public health risks associated with natural gas.
I support Measure B4 which calls for replacing existing natural gas space and water heating systems with electric appliances in Bellingham by 2040.
I support Measure B5 which would require that only electric systems and appliances be installed in new construction within Bellingham city limits.
I need the City to provide more information before I decide if I do or do not support the measures.
